Title:
Higher mammal phylogeny: the morphological-molecular
synthesis.
Abstract:
The basic outlines of higher mammalian relationships are
easily drawn. Since the early 19th century (1), biologists have
recognized a three way division for the living groups of mammals.
Monotremes, including the platypus and echidna from Australia, represent
the sister taxon to the Theria, a group split into the Metatheria
(marsupials) and the Eutheria (‘placentals’). Aside from some
ambiguities in molecular results (2,3) modern investigations only serve
to strengthen this general framework for the mammalian tree. At slightly
lower levels, solutions are more elusive. Particularly vexing is the
problem of relationships among the orders of eutherian mammals. This
array of morphologically diverse creatures, including mice, men, whales,
bats and aardvarks, is customarily depicted as a great polytomous
radiation. One might logically suspect, however, that a more sequential
history of branching underlies this polytomy. In recent years there have
been attempts to discover an overall pattern for eutherians that is
consistent with diverse molecular and morphological data, and some
patterns are emerging. This is a report on revisions of morphological
character data for higher groupings of mammals. The phylogenetic
implications of the revised data are briefly examined and are compared
with molecular results. I shall not review the development of thought
pertaining to current taxonomic controversies or details of character
analyses. These matters are amply covered in a number of recent
papers.
